elements: My Foe is vulnerable to certain distractions. [You can find out exactly what through experimentation or revelation.]
My Foe is vulnerable to this particular distraction... which might help me decide where best to face him.
There is a complication, but this much Edge would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Forge would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Grail would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Heart would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Knock would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Lantern would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Moth would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Secret Histories would resolve it.
There is a complication, but this much Winter would resolve it.
Used to mark rkx internal components
Doctor op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
sanatorium op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
Miracles op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
flowermaker op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
horned op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
wolf op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
smuggling op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
import op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
fights op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
uprising op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
betrayal op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
patronage op marker: DO NOT TRANSLATE
Finite, like a lifetime. [Supplies are consumed when used.]
recipe aspect: populates an operation with third escalation event spawns
recipe aspect: populates an operation with second escalation event spawns
recipe aspect: populates an operation with first escalation event spawns
recipe aspect - hit an foe with a weapon
recipe aspect - hit an underling with a weapon
hidden mutation applied to domicile that infallibly brings the Foe if an rkx verb is running
Defeated at least one underling and proved it corpsily
Sent a weapon to the Foe
A place dedicated to an Hour of struggle and conflict.
A secret shrine of a secret god: the power sometimes known as the Colonel. My Foe had some dealings with the Colonel, and my old mob was discouraged from visiting his shrines.
If my intelligence is correct, there's a cult of the Colonel somewhere in this city.
A secret shrine of a secret god: the power sometimes known as the Lionsmith. My old mob knew to avoid his shrines.
If my intelligence is correct, there's a cult of the Lionsmith somewhere in this city.
Lower-ranked reckoners are just people paid to do bad things. Higher-ranked reckoners are cunning, well-connected and armoured in stolen years.
I've sent funds ahead to make life in this place easier. [Once you've arrived, use this card with Communicate again to retrieve your funds.]
My pursuers have already established a presence here.
Cunning may answer Strength, Strength may answer Cunning, but how might we answer Agony?
Years from the lives of others: bought, stolen or extorted.
I might find safety here for a little longer...
It'll be a long hard journey. But, in my current circumstances, perhaps that should make it more attractive. [Travelling to this Destination is more expensive, but will earn you an Obscurity.]
This place has seen better days. [It's harder to purchase desirable things in Troubled cities, and there may be other effects.]

The time may come when I can run no further. Then I must choose whether to lose myself in the loneliest place I can find... or choose that place to turn and face my Foe. [It's not possible to leave an End location.]
'Reach for the book - it is a weapon.' - Brecht
Something with no uses is, literally, useless.
Allows multiple elements to count towards Foe damage
Allows multiple elements to count towards Underling damage
A fine weapon, but a worldly one. [Ordinary weapons can harm most of your pursuers, but not your Foe.]
At the right angle, anything can be a weapon.
I don't know precisely what the Ligeia Club is; but all reckoners do know that its members are older and hungrier than any of our mobs. We've learnt to avoid them.
Something that won't object to being owned.
If I had to convert this into cash, how much would it be worth?
Some things are too precious to buy with money. Fewer things are too precious to buy with heartbeats.
'PRICE, n. Value, plus a reasonable sum for the wear and tear of conscience in demanding it.' - Bierce. [Provide this or greater in Worth.]
Room for a venue, or a base of operations.
There are joys that even money can't buy. This is not numbered among them.
I've won their trust. They'll follow me when I leave.
They're not here any more. I should make sure I'm not, either.
Proof of a victory. This is going to make my Foe very upset.
Payout aspect for operations DO NOT TRANSLATE
FNORD Heart or Grail dr complication
FNORD Heart or Knock dr complication
FNORD Heart or Grail dr complication
FNORD Heart or Knock dr complication
NB this is in addition to the cult seed base payout
NB this is in addition to the cult seed base payout
NB this is in addition to the cult seed base payout
The congregation are hungry for something more. [If you achieve at least one Effectiveness when running a Faith-Healing Cult, you might be able to establish an Esoteric Cult.]
Some monsters are the Lionsmith's children; some are Echidna's; some are both. Others are worse.
'Everybody needs money. That's why they call it money.' - Mamet
An asset that might travel with you.
With a little time, this will recover.
'There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact.' - Arthur Conan Doyle.  [Anything with this aspect can be used to defeat Traces.]
[Each level of Subtlety reduces the risk of spawning a Trace.]
[Each level of Effectiveness improves the final result.]
A considerable sum. I wouldn't want to be caught carrying this much.
There's a side chapel in Aachen cathedral to a warrior saint who fought against the Persians. On certain days, a deacon will lock the door and perform unorthodox ceremonies for veterans
Roadside Shrine to an Iron Saint
Beneath a rocky overhang, an ancient cast-iron statue stands in a whitewashed shelter. Its face has been scarred to unrecognisability, but one hand still holds a spear.

Unexpectedly, here's a Buddhist temple with painted doors and stained glass windows. But the paint is peeling and most of the windows have been boarded up. A certain Red Army battalion commander has taken the place over - supposedly for storage, but those of us who know the pass-words are permitted to join in stern ceremonies before the scarred face of the Buddha.

In the deepest cellar of the Nationaltheater stands a stern image carved of Black Forest oak. Sixty years ago the Swan King staged a grandiose première of his favourite composer's new opera. It didn't go well. The stage-trappings were banished down here and forgotten. Now the image's eye has been scarred out to make him blind, and those who know of the place's power perform their harsh devotions before it.
In a burnt-out hunting lodge at the edge of town, charred bone has been carved into chess-pieces, and a chess-board scored in the stone of the hearth.

An abandoned grain silo has been adopted by a secret cult honouring an odd hero: the one-armed Briton who stormed the city for the White Russians, alone in a single tank. Perhaps he is now a Name. Perhaps he's only dead. But those who venerate the Colonel remember him.

Malta is the Nurse of the Mediterranean, where soldiers come to be healed, and there are those among the healers who practice the invisible arts. They keep shrines in locked rooms in their hospitals to invoke the healing Hours. No-one prays to the Colonel for healing. They only visit this rotting room under the eaves to invoke him when death would be a mecy.
The Forge of Days does not usually favour libraries, but the Serapeum has made a commitment to non-combustible materials.

There is a dark Wood that presses against the windows of the sleeping mind. There is a nest in the branches woven of black silk and white hair. Zulfiya has prepared a feast to take me there tonight, and inked something on the skin of my back, which she claims is a map I must not see.

Two hundred years ago, an immortal named Hokobald worked alchemy here. In another hundred years, it may slide into the canal. It's wreathed in mist and prowled by gloomy dead, but Orsolina believes its vault has never been breached.

For fifty years this secret yeshiva has taught the Four Traditions of the Bei Ilai: the imprisonment of spirits, the expulsion of monsters, the conclusion of tenacious curses and the sealing of troublesome portals. We'll have to find it to breach it; the rabbis and students will give us difficulty; and the Undergoer itself may need to be subdued.

The authorities maintain a clandestine department dedicated to teratogenic phenomena. Once we've found its location, we'll have to breach its walls and weather the ghastly influences radiating from its heart.
In the sewers below Aachen prowls one of the Lionsmith's less dignified works. We'll have to locate a hidden entrance and survive the sewers' atmosphere before we face the Feaster itself.
The family of the Duc de Tarascon has long been rumoured to breed monsters. They've employed French and German deserters to guard their mist-shrouded chateau.

High in the Alpujarras, there is an enclave of those who dance for the Thunderskin. They dislike being spied upon, and unless I prevent it, they will enact their dislike on the painter Mireya. I'll have to fight their sendings off and stay awake until dawn.
A charming brick house with crow-stepped gables and a pair of venerable pines at the front door. In the attic, the Mamurren perform their rites of pain and courage. This will hurt.
When I woke from the Wood, this is what I found in the sealed bottle beside my bed.

When active, an undergoer is a flexile, half-formed, horribly alluring thing, eager to consume or be impregnated by mortals. But in its dormant state, it's a friendly knot of tentacled flesh, cawing, dribbling and snoring by turns.
The 'seasoning' Dominykas wanted: a pot of nasty-looking larval remnants. The pot is icy cold to the touch.
It's dissolving quickly as its internal structures corrode.
Jannings says that some lessons can only be written on skin. That might be so, but it might be that Jannings just enjoys his work a little too much.
We switch it to a slightly different element so it doesn't get consumed by the ally recruitment recipe.
Jannings says that some lessons can only be written on skin. That might be so, but it might be that Jannings just enjoys his work a little too much.

One of my congregation knows things when they touch the skin of strangers, as long as their fingers are a little damp. They enjoy it far too much, too. [A Flowermaker Cult generates a cultist if you achieve at least one Effectiveness.]
'I can't stop thinking about them. I should sleep.'
One of my congregation has achieved a preternatural understanding of where entities begin, and where they end.[A Horned-Axe Cult generates a cultist if you achieve at least one Effectiveness.]
'That was the day. Now this is the night.'
One of my congregation is eager to embrace their  end. [A Wolf Divided Cult generates a cultist if you achieve at least one Effectiveness.]
Zulfiya never goes anywhere without her scissors.
A muscular woman with a steady gaze. Her diet has changed since her days in the Lionsmith's service, but she still retains some of her old strength.
A smoothly handsome man whose unhuman ancestry is not apparent, unless you know to look for his abnormally flexible fingers, or wonder why his nose tends to run.
Dominykas has a ready smile and an unfortunate habit of picking his teeth.
A lithe, hard-faced Berber woman in the grey-brown striped jellaba of a French-Moroccan auxiliary.
A melancholy and philosophical smuggler of rare cigarettes, rare poisons and rarer weapons.
A plump, dreamy, hesitant woman with very bright eyes.
A specialist in disassembly and also in assembly.
Zulfiya has left a scrawled note indicating that she will be 'walking the Wood' for some time yet.
To recover her strength, Orsolina needs time alone and close to the earth.
Vasil's exertions have softened his shape. For now he has retreated, dripping and cawing, to somewhere warmer.
Dominykas has left to replenish himself, at the hearth and with the shovel.
Chaima has gone wherever she goes to lick her wounds in darkness.
Giorgiou is in hiding until (he says) his nerves have recovered.
Mireya is hiding, shivering, beneath her coverlet.
Jannings has retired from the field until his new supplies arrive.
Zulfiya never goes anywhere without her scissors.
A muscular woman with a steady gaze. Her diet has changed since her days in the Lionsmith's service, but she still retains some of her old strength.
A smoothly handsome man whose unhuman ancestry is not apparent, unless you know to look for his abnormally flexible fingers, or wonder why his nose tends to run.
Dominykas has a ready smile and an unfortunate habit of picking his teeth.
A lithe, hard-faced Berber woman in the grey-brown striped jellaba of a French-Moroccan auxiliary.
A melancholy and philosophical smuggler of rare cigarettes, rare poisons and rarer weapons.
A plump, dreamy, hesitant woman with very bright eyes.
A specialist in disassembly and also in assembly.
Zulfiya has left a scrawled note indicating that she will be 'walking the Wood' for some time yet.
To recover her strength, Orsolina needs time alone and close to the earth.
Vasil's exertions have softened his shape. For now he has retreated, dripping and cawing, to somewhere warmer.
Dominykas has left to replenish himself, at the hearth and with the shovel.
Chaima has gone wherever she goes to lick her wounds in darkness.
Giorgiou is in hiding until (he says) his nerves have recovered.
Mireya is hiding, shivering, beneath her coverlet.
Jannings has retired from the field until his new supplies arrive.
A battered-looking rifle sits prosaically on a counter in an antique shop.
This would be illegal, if enough people knew it existed. [A Forge curio.]
not unique: can be purchased multiple times
Something viscous and sweet.[A Grail curio.]
not unique: can be purchased multiple times
Opportunity: Purchase a Crudely Carved Image?
'Authentic,' I'm assured, 'just like the real thing.' [A Heart curio.]
This kind of thing is one reason I don't go to church. [A Knock curio.]
A fistful of badly mistreated pages.[A Lantern curio.]
A fistful of badly mistreated pages.[A Lantern curio.]
A fistful of badly mistreated pages.[A Lantern curio.]
'It'll be back,' the seller informs me, gloomily. 'Do what you can with it in the meantime.' [A Moth curio.]
Opportunity: Purchase an Odd Little Bone?
They found it in a furnace, I'm told. [A Forge rarity.]
A certain musician has fallen on hard times. It will break her heart to part with this treasure, but a woman must eat. [A Heart rarity.]
Opportunity: Purchase a Map of Secrets
There's always a way. [A Knock rarity.]
A window on to what wasn't. [A Moth rarity.]
I'm told the artist died the night before he completed it. [A Winter rarity.]
Opportunity: Purchase a Case of Extraordinary Wine?
'God made only water, but man made wine' - Victor Hugo. [A Grail rarity.]
I can lease a quiet place to work. [An Office provides a little Space, and, as a place of shelter, a little Heart.]
I can lease space somewhere out of the way. [A Warehouse provides significant Space. As a good place to rest up or work on noisy projects, it also provides both Heart and Forge.]

I can acquire property. [A Townhouse provides significant Space. As a good place to take refuge or entertain guests, it provides both Heart and Grail. If you plan to retire here, it will also provide considerable Comfort.]
I can acquire property. [A Villa provides significant Space, Forge, Heart, and Grail. If you plan to retire here, it will also provide tremendous Comfort.]
I could take this opportunity to qualify, extremely rapidly, as a doctor.
Certain goods are normally restricted; but I have friends now.
I could always use more friends.
Opportunity: a Connection with a Ruler?
A chance to get acquainted with someone of real importance.
Opportunity: a Connection with a Holy Man?
This might have consequences. But I'm probably not planning to stick around.
They're no friends of the reckoner mobs.
This will sit handsomely on a shelf, if I ever have shelves again.
A pinch of this goes up like lightning-struck thermite.
I'd say it tasted like blood, if it didn't taste so good.
Ugly little thing, but there's a cheering warmth to it.
A nasty little illustration of what the pagans used to get up to. Or the Church. I don't know the history. I do know this icon has some kind of power over locks.
Curio: Pages from the Book of Suns

Gorgeously illustrated manuscript pages, ripped from the original binding to be sold separately. I don't know the language - Persian? Arabic? but somehow I can read the words in sufficiently bright light. A dispute between Hours, a lineage concealed, a secret which shattered loyalties... not much practical information, but there's something about the sounds that sharpens the soul.
It smells like unopened rooms. Somehow I keep thinking it's changing its shape when I don't look at it, but I never catch it in the act. [No-one will buy this.]
Tiny, fragile-looking, but it packs a hell of a wallop.

A ten-stringed guitar from the House of Stradivari, shaped from softly glowing Illyrian maple and inlaid with a design of almond leaves and pomegranates. I'd heard one had been stolen from the Gräfin von Grese's collection last year. It might be the last of its kind in a playable condition.
Rarity: The Book of Suns, Reassembled

There's a forgotten and golden truth in these images - a truth from the times before the Sun was divided. I don't understand it. It's not meant for me. But even the reflected light of that truth is an illumination.
This began life as an atlas of the cities of Europe. Over decades it's been extended and annotated by a dozen hands - adepts, burglars, soldiers, spies - to show secret routes and hiding-nooks.
An oil painting of a final horizon, in green-and-gold and glory.
An oil painting of a city foundered in deep snow. Behind its bleakest tower, a sickle moon rises.

A great vintage wrung from a terroir ripe with secrets in the times before the Grand Blight. With discipline, patience, and resolution, it is possible to taste a glass of this wine and not to finish the bottle.
Not too obvious, and not too far out of the way.
There's plenty of space here, although not much else to recommend it.
The envy of every passerby. Let's close the curtains tightly.
I could live out my days here very happily, if it weren't for certain immediate practical difficulties...
The name on the licence isn't exactly mine, but it's close enough.
The name on the licence isn't exactly mine, but it's close enough.
A mutually beneficial arrangement with someone in authority.
A mutually beneficial arrangement with someone of real power.
A mutually beneficial arrangement with a learned holy man.
A mutually beneficial arrangement with revolutionaries or other enthusiasts.
A mutually beneficial arrangement with relevant professionals.
A ticket to the very first destination that came to mind -
I stole this from my Foe's personal collection, the night I took the years. I may yet need it.

An antique rifle incised with the five-fold mark of the Many-Winged Ones. Three taenite-iron balls - monster-killers - remain. [The Lionhunter's Rifle refreshes quickly, but it can only be fired three times.]

An antique rifle incised with the five-fold mark of the Many-Winged Ones. Two taenite-iron balls - monster-killers - remain. [The Lionhunter's Rifle refreshes quickly, but it can only be fired twice more.]
An antique rifle incised with the five-fold mark of the Many-Winged Ones. Only one taenite-iron ball remains. [The Lionhunter's Rifle refreshes quickly, but it can only be fired once more.]

In its long career, this weapon has also been called Gatemaker, Scarsword, and the Orphan. It was commissioned to be borne by kings against sieged cities, but it will cut bits off mortals and immortals just fine.

A cut from this blade will not cease bleeding until the wound is healed. One account has it that Biedde was a knife-collecting surgeon-highwayman in eighteenth-century Toulouse. Another claims Biedde is only the bastardisation of an Arabic word for 'mosquito'. But my Foe used to number Biedde among the Colonel's Names.
It doesn't look like much, but at its touch, flesh perishes. Perhaps it really is a last fragment of the weapon that slew the Seven-Coiled from within.
I stole this from my Foe's personal collection, the night I took the years. I may yet need it.
An antique rifle incised with the five-fold mark of the Many-Winged Ones. [The Lionhunter's Rifle refreshes quickly, but it can only be fired twice more.]
An antique rifle incised with the five-fold mark of the Many-Winged Ones. [The Lionhunter's Rifle refreshes quickly, but it can only be fired once more.]

In its long career, this weapon has also been called Gatemaker, Scarsword, and the Orphan. It was commissioned to be borne by kings against sieged cities, but it will cut bits off mortals and immortals just fine.

A cut from this blade will not cease bleeding until the wound is healed. One account has it that Biedde was a knife-collecting surgeon-highwayman in eighteenth-century Toulouse. Another claims Biedde is only the bastardisation of an Arabic word for 'mosquito'. But my Foe used to number Biedde among the Colonel's Names.
It doesn't look like much, but at its touch, flesh perishes. Perhaps it really is a last fragment of the weapon that slew the Seven-Coiled from within.
This might be the only defence against the reckoner lords. It might be no defence at all.

I've stolen a fortune in years from a reckoner lord who trusted me. He'll pursue me across continents, but even his reach has limits. [Achieve seven Obscurity to send a taunting message to your reckoner Foe, disappear forever, and win the game.]
None of this has gone as I planned. But I'd still like to retire in style.
Ten years of generously donated life, as entered in the Cindered Tally.
A year of generously donated life, as entered in the Cindered Tally.
A betraying clue that my pursuers might recognise.
The light is famously good - enough so that a small colony of artists toils here - but it's still an optimistic name for a storm-beaten tumble of Baltic granite.
Deep in the taiga forests of Siberia, a hunting lodge decays gracefully into an ice-blue lake - a lake, it's said, that a falling moon-fragment scarred from the forest.
On a high far limestone plateau in the greatest of deserts, the Mozabites built five citadel villages to be a refuge for their people. Now, one is a refuge for me.
Across the deadly sands, an oasis where peculiarly healthy villagers thrive. In the hills above, a sunny, rocky cell of three windows.

In the little sea called Morbihan, the gate to the western ocean, there's an isle famed for its sailors. On its westmost tip lies a quiet priory. The monks enjoy their privacy, but they've been known to offer sanctuary.
High in the abode of eternal snows, a monastery of the Diamond Vehicle clings improbably to a cliff face like flowers on lichen.
On an icy promontory in northernmost Norway, a lonely lighthouse stands proudly with its back to the ocean.
The light is famously good - enough so that a small colony of artists toils here - but it's still an optimistic name for a storm-beaten tumble of Baltic granite.
Deep in the taiga forests of Siberia, a hunting lodge decays gracefully into an ice-blue lake - a lake, it's said, that a falling moon-fragment scarred from the forest.
On a high far limestone plateau in the greatest of deserts, the Mozabites built five citadel villages to be a refuge for their people. Now, one is a refuge for me.
Across the deadly sands, an oasis where peculiarly healthy villagers thrive. In the hills above, a sunny, rocky cell of three windows.

In the little sea called Morbihan, the gate to the western ocean, there's an isle famed for its sailors. On its westmost tip lies a quiet priory. The monks enjoy their privacy, but they've been known to offer sanctuary.
High in the abode of eternal snows, a monastery of the Diamond Vehicle clings improbably to a cliff face like flowers on lichen.
On an icy promontory in northernmost Norway, a lonely lighthouse stands proudly with its back to the ocean.
Republics come and republics go since the Great War. Just now, Aachen has its own republic under French patronage. I should be gone before it collapses.

Dignified men of business in tall red hats and immaculate white suits outside the Bourse; British soldiers bickering drunkenly by a melon-slice stall; theosophists playing backgammon in the Cafe Al Aktar. At the Rialto in Safiya Zaghloul, they're showing a German film about waxworks, but the power goes off and on and off again. Behind the curtain of night, the Invisible Serapeum waits.
Pine scent and bougainvillea, white walls and ocean light, sirocco winds and the smoulder of revolution.

The Golden Age is over, but glory lingers like fading music. Bicycles rattle across cobbles. A woman in white throws open the shutters of a high window. On misty evenings, the Nameless Name of the Velvet walks here.
Sleepy Avignon, where the mistral blows.

Baking heat, dusty orange trees, tiled and genteel decay. The Ottomans did not favour Baghdad. Now the British have imported a Syrian puppet king, and alternate between building hospitals and bombing the locals into bloody compliance. The city is probably due another rebellion any day now.

Winter in Budapest, and the Danube is dusted with snow. The Dual Monarchy has collapsed, but somehow this city is once again the capital of the Kingdom of Hungary. The King has twice tried to return, and twice been driven out. Politics.

A hard two decades. The Asia Minor Disaster; independence, and the Union with Greece; and then a monkey bit the King to death. But the Cretans and their island have endured four thousand years, and they endure still. The harbour is mountainous with fortifications, but Heraklion lies quiet in the afternoon sun.
Nestled in the mountains of sunset lies the city of the Archangel Michael. I remember it mostly as the place where I drank too much tsuica and got into a fight with bricklayers. We've all been young.
Cold clean air and hushed white streets and green-splashed patios and the mountains looking down. I might find something like respite.
Seven hills, three names, two continents and a hundred thousand cats. The bustle of the Grand Bazaar and the sudden silent dazzle of the Golden Horn.

Half of Lithuania has fallen to Poland, and the peace is desperately fragile, but this is the capital now. They call it Little Paris, and the lamplight glows in the cafes and the dance halls. But there is a new president, and now the Association of the Iron Wolf begins to tighten its jaws.
The city of the black earth and the golden gate. For a little while it was free, but first the Marshal and then the Red Army put an end to that.
The castle on the hill where the dragon died looks out across a city mellow with October sunlight. Just don't speak ill of the Marshal.

Lenin is dead, and the old capital now carries his name. It carries, too, the scars of the Revolution, of the Red Terror, and now of the September Deluge. The streets still stink of the Neva mud. In a dim curtained office high in the Tauride Palace, Zinoviev awaits Stalin's next move.

Mass strikes and martial law have paralysed the big smoke this month. Tanks rumble along Pall Mall. Agitators conspire in the city's lethal fogs. Perhaps the Nameless Name will shield me with her mists...
Five hundred miles away, the Republic of the Rif wages guerilla war against the French Protectorate. But here in Marrakech it's still mint tea and parasols.

A mild and turquoise sunset in Meshad, and the lights along Khayam Boulevard flickering to life. Armoured cars growl past: the new Shah is wary. A thousand years ago, here between the mountains, Ferdowsi wrote: 'How shall a man escape from that which is written; How shall he flee from his destiny?' It's a good question, actually.

Munich is still a gracious city, and the chestnuts are very lovely in the spring. But hatreds old and new, and the privations of the Great War, make it a difficult place just now. More so since the beer-hall business last year with Ludendorff and that godawful little Austrian.

For a hundred years, here where the Volga and the Oka meet, all the riches of old Russia and beyond have met at Nizhny Great Fair. Now the Red Army garrisons the echoing old spaces, but still the goods come. Copper, salt, grain, tea; wool, coal, nails, flesh.
This year in the City of Lights, the socialists battle the communists, the Métro grumbles, gaunt artists prowl bookshops on the Other Bank. Plus ça change.

The City of a Hundred Spires, flexing its republican muscles beneath the benign gaze of Masaryk and his Castlemen. Statues watch the bridges each night. This is Europe's heart, and for a while longer, it will beat with cheery vigour.
Beyond the kerosene bustle of the great port, here by the dark sea where the amber comes to light, ancient clockwork drives the Warnemünde Lighthouse. Each night it winks at the horizon.
The metropolis of the conqueror Timur, the crossroads of the silk trade, the city of a hundred faiths. The Tsars and now the Bolsheviks have ruled here since the Manghit emirs were ousted.
Midnight in Stalingrad. Everywhere, statues of the Georgian radiate avuncular menace across the moonlit streets.

Here were sworn the great oaths that divided the empire of the great Charles between east and west. In consequence, the land has been contested for a thousand years; in consequence, the shadow of the Horned Axe lies long here. Also, there's a cheery little bistro where they serve that stew with juniper and white wine that I like.
This was always the city of the jewel-merchants and the malachite miners. Now the Bolsheviks are remaking it as a crucible of heavy industry.

The falcon-king found the sulphur-springs, and built his city here. Now it's the capital of the Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic, and there are motor-cars, a telegraph office. Progress.
Flower-thronged Tirana, where Zogist soldiers crowd the cafes with drunken laughter, where the Flowermaker hums his dreamy songs in the bee-droning shadows.

The Spanish took Tripoli from the Berbers, the Knights of St John took it from the Spanish, the Ottomans took it from the Knights, and now the Italians run the place. The Berbers called Tripoli 'the Bride of the Sea'. And, if I can believe my Foe, my mother called it 'home'.
Sunny seat of the Crown Colony of Malta. British sailors saunter along the sloping streets. The battleship Royal Rose dominates the harbour like an iron cathedral.

Deep fog has made Venice a pale city more heard than seen: the plash of waves, the purr of vaporettos, the scent of seaweed and sewage. The sun is a blind eye. If ever the Nameless Name of the Velvet walks by day, she must walk here.

One of those few cities which has the same name in every History... if you believe that sort of thing. For a very long time it was the first heart of the Dual Empire, and for the longest time the adepts have known it as the White City. But now it's Red Vienna under the First Republic, and the streets are bright with dawn.
Rhenish separatists are fighting German loyalists in the streets. I should leave while I still can.
Nationalists are fighting French troops in the streets. I should leave while I still can.
Hashemite forces are fighting nationalists in the streets. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Police are fighting pitched battles with workers in the streets. I should leave while I still can.
Communists and and nationalists are fighting street-to-street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Soviets and Jadidists are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Revolutionaries and counter-revolutionaries are fighting street to street. I should leave while I still can.
Republics come and republics go since the Great War. Just now, Aachen has its own republic under French patronage. I should be gone before it collapses.

Dignified men of business in tall red hats and immaculate white suits outside the Bourse; British soldiers bickering drunkenly by a melon-slice stall; theosophists playing backgammon in the Cafe Al Aktar. At the Rialto in Safiya Zaghloul, they're showing a German film about waxworks, but the power goes off and on and off again. Behind the curtain of night, the Invisible Serapeum waits.
Pine scent and bougainvillea, white walls and ocean light, sirocco winds and the smoulder of revolution.

The Golden Age is over, but glory lingers like fading music. Bicycles rattle across cobbles. A woman in white throws open the shutters of a high window. On misty evenings, the Nameless Name of the Velvet walks here.
Sleepy Avignon, where the mistral blows.

Baking heat, dusty orange trees, tiled and genteel decay. The Ottomans did not favour Baghdad. Now the British have imported a Syrian puppet king, and alternate between building hospitals and bombing the locals into bloody compliance. The city is probably due another rebellion any day now.

Winter in Budapest, and the Danube is dusted with snow. The Dual Monarchy has collapsed, but somehow this city is once again the capital of the Kingdom of Hungary. The King has twice tried to return, and twice been driven out. Politics.

A hard two decades. The Asia Minor Disaster; independence, and the Union with Greece; and then a monkey bit the King to death. But the Cretans and their island have endured four thousand years, and they endure still. The harbour is mountainous with fortifications, but Heraklion lies quiet in the afternoon sun.
Nestled in the mountains of sunset lies the city of the Archangel Michael. I remember it mostly as the place where I drank too much tsuica and got into a fight with bricklayers. We've all been young.
Cold clean air and hushed white streets and green-splashed patios and the mountains looking down. I might find something like respite.
Seven hills, three names, two continents and a hundred thousand cats. The bustle of the Grand Bazaar and the sudden silent dazzle of the Golden Horn.

Half of Lithuania has fallen to Poland, and the peace is desperately fragile, but this is the capital now. They call it Little Paris, and the lamplight glows in the cafes and the dance halls. But there is a new president, and now the Association of the Iron Wolf begins to tighten its jaws.
The city of the black earth and the golden gate. For a little while it was free, but first the Marshal and then the Red Army put an end to that.
The castle on the hill where the dragon died looks out across a city mellow with October sunlight. Just don't speak ill of the Marshal.

Lenin is dead, and the old capital now carries his name. It carries, too, the scars of the Revolution, of the Red Terror, and now of the September Deluge. The streets still stink of the Neva mud. In a dim curtained office high in the Tauride Palace, Zinoviev awaits Stalin's next move.

Mass strikes and martial law have paralysed the Big Smoke this month. Tanks rumble along Pall Mall. Agitators conspire in the city's lethal fogs. Perhaps the Nameless Name will shield me with her mists...
Five hundred miles away, the Republic of the Rif wages guerilla war against the French Protectorate. But here in Marrakech it's still mint tea and parasols.

A mild and turquoise sunset in Meshad, and the lights along Khayam Boulevard flickering to life. Armoured cars growl past: the new Shah is wary. A thousand years ago, here between the mountains, Ferdowsi wrote: 'How shall a man escape from that which is written; How shall he flee from his destiny?' It's a good question, actually.

Munich is still a gracious city, and the chestnuts are very lovely in the spring. But hatreds old and new, and the privations of the Great War, make it a difficult place just now. More so since the beer-hall business last year with Ludendorff and that godawful little Austrian.

For a hundred years, here where the Volga and the Oka meet, all the riches of old Russia and beyond have met at Nizhny Great Fair. Now the Red Army garrisons the echoing old spaces, but still the goods come. Copper, salt, grain, tea; wool, coal, nails, flesh.
This year in the City of Lights, the socialists battle the communists, the Métro grumbles, gaunt artists prowl bookshops on the Other Bank. Plus ça change.

The City of a Hundred Spires, flexing its republican muscles beneath the benign gaze of Masaryk and his Castlemen. Statues watch the bridges each night. This is Europe's heart, and for a while longer, it will beat with cheery vigour.
Beyond the kerosene bustle of the great port, here by the dark sea where the amber comes to light, ancient clockwork drives the Warnemünde Lighthouse. Each night it winks at the horizon.
The metropolis of the conqueror Timur, the crossroads of the silk trade, the city of a hundred faiths. The Tsars and now the Bolsheviks have ruled here since the Manghit emirs were ousted.
Midnight in Stalingrad. Everywhere, statues of the Georgian radiate avuncular menace across the moonlit streets.

Here were sworn the great oaths that divided the empire of the great Charles between east and west. In consequence, the land has been contested for a thousand years; in consequence, the shadow of the Horned Axe lies long here. Also, there's a cheery little bistro where they serve that stew with juniper and white wine that I've always liked so much.
This was always the city of the jewel-merchants and the malachite miners. Now the Bolsheviks are remaking it as a crucible of heavy industry.

The falcon-king found the sulphur-springs, and built his city here. Now it's the capital of the Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic, and there are motor-cars, a telegraph office. Progress.
Flower-thronged Tirana, where Zogist soldiers crowd the cafes with drunken laughter, where the Flowermaker hums his dreamy songs in the bee-droning shadows.

The Spanish took Tripoli from the Berbers, the Knights of St John took it from the Spanish, the Ottomans took it from the Knights, and now the Italians run the place. The Berbers called Tripoli 'the Bride of the Sea'. And, if I can believe my Foe, my mother called it 'home'.
Sunny seat of the Crown Colony of Malta. British sailors saunter along the sloping streets. The battleship Royal Rose dominates the harbour like an iron cathedral.

Deep fog has made Venice a pale city more heard than seen: the plash of waves, the purr of vaporettos, the scent of seaweed and sewage. The sun is a blind eye. If ever the Nameless Name of the Velvet walks by day, she must walk here.

One of those few cities which has the same name in every History... if you believe that sort of thing. For a very long time it was the first heart of the Dual Empire, and for the longest time the adepts have known it as the White City. But now it's Red Vienna under the First Republic, and the streets are bright with dawn.
Out into the wilds. This should be my last resort. [Few opportunities of any use, and you can't survive out there for long.]
There are always choices. I could die of thirst, or cold, or hunger. [Few opportunities of any use, and you'll have to take whatever road onwards presents itself.]
The air shimmers like a naked furnace. Serpents' weather.
The sea bears gifts: peace, or death, or escape.
I've passed a place of worship.
I've found a place bristling with excitable cats.
A high place. Don't look down.
The smell of hawthorn, and the colour of sunset bisected with shadow. The Horned Axe is strong here.
That scent which is neither tar nor blood nor ozone. The Wolf-Divided's rage boils beneath the air.
Here are sweet airs, here are the beginnings of dreams... here our thoughts turn to the Hour called Flowermaker.
Here at the desert's edge, the thing that calls itself 'Mme E' doesn't always bother with human form. With luck, I'll never see what shape it prefers.
I know that Frau Schlüssel has lived here since long before the siege. If I don't call her attention, perhaps I'll be safe.
Whatever 'Our Lady of Wires' might be, it has chosen Kiev for its feeding-grounds this year.
In all of this city, there is not one statue whose eyes are not wide open. Why is that?
Mme Matutine's yacht, the Sapphire, lies at harbour here. Mme Matutine has a lethal reputation.
Sulochana Amavasya lairs at the Ecdysis Club, but she's abroad in the city this week. I should avoid her.
Sunrise, when the world is clean.
Sunset, when the light is richer.
The deep watches of the night, and again I can't sleep.
Some there are who will not yield. Perhaps this is a virtue.
Even in a life like mine, there are moments when it's possible to think: what may come, may come.
'Beware the fury of a patient man.' - Dryden, 'Absalom and Achitophel'
Seven of these will end me.
This wound could cost me ten years - unless I replace those years.
Seven of these will end my enemy.
Seven wounds will end my enemy. [This Wound will take twice as long to heal.]
One more of these will kill my pursuer.
Seven wounds will kill my pursuer. [This Wound will take twice as long to heal.]
The reckoner mob has turned its attention to this city. [Informants won't harm you directly, but more dangerous enemies may follow if they find you.]
I recognised a face in the street. We worked together once. Was I spotted?[Reckoner Operatives will try to steal your Assets.]
Someone is asking after me. I recognise the description, too well. [Assassins will try to murder you.]
A reckoner lieutenant, winnowed from the ranks by ferocity and guile, grown sleek on borrowed years. [Underbosses may steal assets, attack you directly, or summon the Foe.]
Seasoned like oak and scarred like sea-cliffs. I have seen his strength, and I would be a fool not to fear it.
How many times did this heart beat? How many of those beats were stolen from another? It is withering now.
The rumours are true - snow makes my Foe slow and stupid.
The rumours are true - when the weather is hot enough, my foe becomes slow and stupid.
All reckoners treat the sea with caution. But it's true what I've heard: my Foe fears its touch.
A religious upbringing? A persistent superstition? My enemy is reluctant to desecrate holy places.
My Foe fears cats! He's long been ready to murder anyone who even hinted as much. Now I know why.
High places dizzy and demoralise my Foe.
The Horned Axe does not favour my Foe, and where its shadow falls, he hesitates.
If half the stories of this thing are true, it hates everything with near-equal incandescence. But in my Foe's case, the Wolf's rage burns a fraction hotter.
Something about the Flowermaker's influence confounds my Foe. I may never know exactly what.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
If I can uncover this weakness, it'll give me an advantage.
